summary: 01/01/2000: A Civil Guard barracks in Galdacano, Vizcaya Province was attacked by Basque radicals with 36 petrol bombs. One person was injured and an unknown amount of damage was done to the facilities.
target1: Civil Guard barracks in Galdacano, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 36 petrol bombs were thrown at the barracks
scite1: “Spain: Basque Radicals Fire-Bomb Civil Guard Barracks,” EFE, January 1, 2000.

summary: 01/01/2000: A bank in Gernika, Vizcaya Province, was attacked with petrol bombs by unknown perpetrators. Damage was caused to the reception area and windows were broken. No injuries or fatalities were reported.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Petrol bombs were thrown inside the bank
propcomment: The windows of the bank were broken and the inside, mainly the reception area, was damaged by petrol bombs
scite1: “Spain: Basque Radicals Fire-Bomb Civil Guard Barracks,” EFE, January 1, 2000.

summary: 01/02/2000: The Thuringian Interior Ministry in Erfurt, Germany, was attacked when unknown persons threw a Molotov cocktail at the building from a car. The device landed in front of the building stairs, causing no damage. A previous attack on the building on December 21, 1999, was claimed by the Autonomous Decorators , in protest of the arrest of three members of the Revolutionary Cells/Red Zora. It was speculated that this attack was committed by the same perpetrators.
target1: The Thuringian Interior Ministry office in Erfurt
motive: Possibly in protest of the arrest of three members of the Revolutionary Cells/Red Zora group.
weapdetail: A Molotov cocktail was thrown at the building.
scite1: “Two Attacks on Thuringian Interior Ministry Reported,” ddpADN, January 4, 2000.

summary: 01/03/2000: A car belonging to the Jordanian Embassy was torched in the Athens suburb of Aghia Paraskevi. A call was later made to a radio station claiming responsibility by the Anarchist Faction, wanting the liberation of individuals Kostas Kalaremas and Nikolaos Maziotis.
target1: A car belonging to the Jordanian Embassy in Athens
motive: The perpetators wanted the liberation of Kostas Kalaremas and Nikolaos Maziotis.
propcomment: The car was burned
addnotes: The claim of responsibility was made on a Greek radio station.
scite1: “Jordanian Embassy Car Torched in Athens,” (Internet) Athens News Agency WWW, January 3, 2000.
scite2: Nivin ‘Abd-Al-Hadi, “Envoy Says Athens Car Attack Does Not Target Jordan,” Amman Al-Dustur, January 4, 2000.
scite3: Petros Kasiotis, “Arson Attacks by Greek Anarchist Group Seen,” Elevtheros Tipos, January 4, 2000.

summary: 01/04/2000: A group of Basque radicals threw 13 petrol bombs at the front of the Civil Guard barracks in Durango, Vizcaya Province, Spain. None of the petrol bombs exploded and there was no damage or injuries.
target1: Civil Guard barracks in Durango, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 13 petrol bombs were thrown at the barracks
scite1: “Spain: Basque Radicals Fire-Bomb Civil Guard Barracks,” RNE-1 Radio Network, January 4, 2000.

summary: 01/04/2000: A bomb place outside an Athens branch of the National Bank of Greece by unknown perpetrators was spotted by a bank security guard and defused before it detonated.
target1: The Athens branch of the National Bank of Greece
motive: Unknown
scite1: Petros Kasiotis, “Arson Attacks by Greek Anarchist Group Seen,” Elevtheros Tipos, January 4, 2000.
scite2: “Firebombs damage cars; other bomb fails to detonate outside bank,” Associated Press Worldstream, January 3, 2000.

summary: 01/05/2000: A clothes shop in San Sebastian, Spain, belonging to a socialist activist was attacked by an unknown group. The windows of the store were broken and the shop was set on fire. The window displays and other parts of the store were damaged.
target1: A clothes shop in San Sebastian
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The windows of the shop were broken and the inside damaged by fire and smoke
scite1: “Spain: Arson Attack Damages Shop in Basque Country,” EFE, January 6, 2000.

summary: 01/05/2000: The home of Basque Socialist Party (PSE-EE) member Maria Angeles Gonzalez in Andoain, Guipuzcoa Province, was attacked with petrol bombs. An unknown group of hooded individuals threw three petrol bombs into the home after breaking the windows. No injuries or fatalities were reported.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Three petrol bombs were thrown through the window
propcomment: Fire damaged part of the house
scite1: “Spain: Hooded Basque Gang Fire-Bombs Councillor's Home,” EFE, January 5, 2000.

summary: 01/06/2000: The cash dispensers of two banks, the Banco Guipuzcoano and the Banco Central Hispano, in San Sebastian, Spain, were set on fire by unknown perpetrators.
target1: A cash dispenser at a branch of the Banco Guipuzcoano
target2: A cash dispenser at a branch of the Banco Central Hispano
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The cash dispensers were damaged by fire
scite1: “Spain: Attackers Set Fire To Basque Banks,” EFE, January 6, 2000.

location: County Antrim
summary: 01/07/2000: A pipe bomb exploded in the back garden of a house at Andraid Close in the Stiles Estate in Antrim, Northern Ireland. No one was injured in the attack, which authorities believed might have been related to a murder that occurred at that spot on January 1, 2000, although no group claimed responsibility.
target1: The back garden of a home at the Stiles Estate in Antrim
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A pipe bomb was used
addnotes: Denver Smith, 32, had been murdered at the same location as this incident on January 1, 2000. Three men were charged in connection with his death.
scite1: “Blast in N. Ireland Town; None Injured,” Press Association, January 7, 2000.

summary: 01/08/2000: The offices of the extreme right movement, the National Front in Rome, were damaged by an arson attack. A container of flammable liquid was set on fire in the doorway of the offices. Damage was done to the National Front offices and surrounding buildings had some smoke damage. A phone call was made by the Revolutionary Leninist Brigades claiming responsibility. No injuries or fatalities reported.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The offices of the National Front were damaged and surrounding buildings had smoke damage
scite1: “Italy: Rightst Group Offices Damaged in Arson Attack,” ANSA (Internet version), January 8, 2000.
scite2: “Italy: Leninists Claim Responsibility for Arson Attack,” RAI Televideo Teletext, January 9, 2000.

summary: 01/08/2000: A booster station in Hernani, Guipuzcoa Province, for Airtel, a telecommunications company, was damaged by an attack when unknown persons sprinkled flammable liquid over electronic equipment and set it on fire. Minimal damage was done to the facilities.
target1: A booster station for Airtel in Hernani
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A flammable liquid was put on the equipment
propcomment: The equipment was slightly damaged
scite1: “Spain: Basque Firebombers Target Relay Station, Flats,” EFE, January 8, 2000.

summary: 01/08/2000: Two branches of the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), one branch of the Banco de Comercio, and the ATM at a branch of the Bilbao Bizkaia Kutxa (BBK) bank were attacked with Molotov cocktails causing damage to each facility. Graffiti messages against the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), the Popular Party (PP), and the Basque regional government's interior minister, Javier Balza, were also sprayed on the walls. No injuries were reported, and no group claimed responsibility.
target1: Two branches of the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA) in Gernika
target2: A branch of the Banco de Comercio in Gernika
target3: A cash dispenser at a Bilbao Bizkaia Kutxa (BBK) bank in Gernika
motive: Messages against the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), the Popular Party (PP), and the Basque regional government's interior minister, Javier Balza, were sprayed on the walls.
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were thrown at each facility
propcomment: Each bank branch was slightly damaged
scite1: “Spain: Several Banks Attacked in Basque Town,” EFE, January 9, 2000.
scite2: “Spain: Bank, Car Arson Attacks in Basque Country,” EFE, January 9, 2000.

location: Armagh (County)
summary: 01/10/2000: Commander of an Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) group in Portadown, County Armagh, Richard Jameson was shot repeatedly and killed, probably by members of the UVF split-off Loyalist Volunteer Force (LVF).
target1: Commander of the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) group in Portadown, Richard Jameson
motive: Unknown
scite1: David Sharrock, “Ulster Terrorist Leader Murdered by Rival Faction,” The Daily Telegraph (Internet version), January 11, 2000.
scite2: Chris Anderson, “Ulster Police Expect Loyalist Feud,” The Irish Times (Internet Version), January 11, 2000.
scite3: Deric Henderson, “UK: LVF Blamed After Rival Loyalist Gunned Down,” Press Association, January 10, 2000.

summary: 01/13/2000: The Pontorson tax office in La Manche department, France, was damaged when an explosive device went off outside the office’s door. The office and neighboring houses were damaged when the windows shattered. The perpetrators of this attack were unknown.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The windows of the tax office and surrounding buildings were shattered
scite1: “France: Bomb Attack Damages Tax Office in Northwest,” France-Info Radio, January 13, 2000.

summary: 01/15/2000: Two rockets were fired at the international congress center in Davos, Switzerland, where the World Economic Forum was scheduled for January 27-February 1, 2000. An anonymous message was faxed to a number of media outlets by opponents of the World Trade Organization and globalization.
target1: The international conference center where the World Economic Forum was held a week after the event
motive: An anonymous message was sent by opponents of the World Trade Organization and globalization.
scite1: Konstantin Pribytkov, “TASS Reports Rocket Attack on Davos Congress Center,” ITAR-TASS, January 16, 2000.

summary: 01/21/2000: Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) detonated a car bomb in Madrid killing one army officer and injuring two teenage girls.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was used
scite1: “One Dead, Several Injured in Car Bomb Attack in Madrid,” EFE, January 21, 2000.
scite2: “Pope Condemns Madrid Terrorist Car Bomb Attacks,” ANSA (Internet version), January 23, 2000.
scite3: “Italy's Dini Deplores ETA Car Bomb in Madrid,” (Internet) Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs WWW-Text, January 22, 2000.

summary: 01/23/2000: In Athens an Italian diplomat’s car and a bus owned by a Greek-German school were burned after a group attacked with gas canisters. Both attacks were claimed by phone call by the November 19 Anarchist Faction and Revolutionaries of the Streets.
target2: A bus belonging to a Greek-German school
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The car and bus were burnt
scite1: “Diplomat's car and school bus burned in Athens attacks: police,” Agence France Presse, January 23, 2000.
scite2: “Italian embassy car destroyed in arson attack,” Associated Press Worldstream, January 23, 2000.

summary: 01/26/2000: A group of unknown hooded individuals threw petrol bombs at a number of banks in Getxo. No one was injured and fire caused damage at some of the locations.
target1: A number of bank branches in Getxo
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Petrol bombs were thrown into the banks
propcomment: The bank offices were damaged by fire
scite1: Jon Kepa Idoiaga, “Spain: Hooded Basque Gang Firebombs Bilbao Banks,” RNE-1 Radio Network, January 26, 2000.

summary: 01/29/2000: An unknown group set fire to a railway station in Portugalete, Vizcaya Province, with flammable liquid. The ticket office and machine were significantly damaged.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Flammable liquid was put around the station
propcomment: The ticket machine and office were significantly damaged
scite1: “Spain: Acts of Violence Reported in Basque Country,” EFE, January 30, 2000.
scite2: “Basque Country: Arson Attack on Bilbao Railway Station,” EFE, January 29, 2000.

summary: 01/29/2000: An unknown group threw a Molotov cocktail at a cash dispenser at a Bilbao bank causing damage to the machine.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A Molotov cocktail was thrown at the building
propcomment: The cash dispenser was damaged by fire
scite1: “Spain: Acts of Violence Reported in Basque Country,” EFE, January 30, 2000.

summary: 01/29/2000: The home of Basque Socialist Party (PSE-EE) representative Amaya Goyaran Orbegozo in Lasarte, Guipuzkoa Province, was attacked when an unidentified group threw four incendiary devices into the home. Three of the petrol bombs exploded causing damage to a bathroom and the balcony. Two nearby cars were also damaged by falling debris.
target1: The house of Amaya Goyaran Orbegozo, a PSE-EE member
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Four petrol bombs were thrown into the home
propcomment: A bathroom and the balcony were damaged by fire and two cars were damaged by falling debris
scite1: “Spain: Basque Socialist Councillor's Home Fire-Bombed,” EFE, January 29, 2000.

summary: 01/30/2000: An incendiary device was thrown at the Basque government communications booster station in Hernani, Guipuzcoa Province, by unknown perpetrators.
target1: A Basque government communications booster station
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Spain: Acts of Violence Reported in Basque Country,” EFE, January 30, 2000.

location: Fermanagh (County)
summary: 02/06/2000: Authorities blamed the Continuity Irish Republican Army (CIRA) for bombing a rural hotel in Irvinestown, Northern Ireland. The assailants warned police of this attack and thus civilians were evacuated from the area. There were no casualties reported.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Bomb Explodes at Northern Ireland Hotel,” London Press Association, February 06, 2000.
scite2: “IRA Dissidents Suspected in Bombing,” Associated Press Online, February 06, 2000.
scite3: Ian Graham, “Ulster Peace in Crisis After Hotel Blast,” London Press Association, February 06, 2000.

summary: 02/11/2000: In Amorebieta, Spain, four unidentified perpetrators set a Citroen car dealership on fire, destroying the shop. Although no one claimed credit, the Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) was suspected in the attack.
target1: Citroen Car Dealership in Amorebieta, Spain
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The shop area of the dealership was destroyed.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 02/14/2000: A previously unknown Greek anarchist group calling themselves the Erotic Anti-authority Cells used a gas canister firebomb to attack a Pfizer office building. No one was injured, but the building, located in Thessaloniki, Greece, suffered extensive damage.
target1: Offices of Viagra manufacturing representatives in Thessaloniki, Greece
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb used was homemade, comprised of two small liquid gas canisters and a canister of gasoline.
propcomment: The entrance to the building, the lobby, and several front offices were damaged in the bombing.
scite1: "'Erotic Cells' claim responsibility for attack on Viagra firm," Agence France Presse, February 16, 2000.
scite2: "Viagra-Bomb," Athens News Agency, February 16, 2000.

summary: 02/22/2000: A local Spanish Socialist Party leader, Fernando Buesa Blanco, and his bodyguard were killed in a car bomb attack in Vitoria-Gasteiz, Basque country, Spain. The Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) was suspected responsible for the assassination. Fernando Buesa, the leader of the Alava provincial chapter of the Socialist Party, opposed Basque independence.
target1: Fernando Buesa Blanco, a politician with the Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The explosive used in this attack was a car bomb.
propcomment: The car was damaged in the incident.
scite1: "ETA’s trail of blood,” Agence France Presse, February 22, 2000.
scite2: "Deadly car bomb attack sparks anti-ETA protest in Spain,” Agence France Presse, February 22, 2000.
scite3: "Car bomb blast kills two in Basque capital,” Associated Press Worldstream, February 22, 2000.

location: Londonderry (County)
summary: 02/25/2000: The Continuity IRA (CIRA) bombed the Shackleton Barracks, in Ballykelly, Londonderry, Northern Ireland. No one was killed or injured in the attack however there was minor property damage.
target1: Shackleton Barracks, in Ballykelly, Londonderry, Northern Ireland
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Windows were broken from the explosion.
addnotes: The Continuity IRA (CIRA) claimed responsibility but police believed another faction may have been behind it because an unfamiliar password was used.
scite1: “IRA Rebels Target British Troops On UK Mainland,” Sunday Times, February 27, 2000.
scite2: “Two Held Over Blast at Ulster Barracks,” Press Association, February 26, 2000.
scite3: “Ulster: Device Explodes At Army Barracks; No Casualties,” Press Association, February 25, 2000.

location: Armagh (County)
summary: 02/25/2000: A man was shot and injured by a loyalist gunman as he exited his car in the driveway of his home in Portadown, Northern Ireland. No one else was injured and there was no property damage.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Appeal for Calm After Portadown Shooting,” Press Association, February 26, 2000.
scite2: “UK: Man Shot in Portadown Loyalist Housing Estate,” Press Association, February 25, 2000.

summary: 02/27/2000: A group of hooded individuals tried to burn a carriage belonging to the Basque railway company Eusko Tren while it was at the station in Renteria, Spain. Several passengers were inside the carriage however there were no casualties.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Spain: Arsonists Target Train in Basque Country,” EFE, February 27, 2000.
scite2: “Spanish Press Selection List 04 Mar 00,” Madrid El Pais, March 4, 2000.

summary: 02/27/2000: Unknown persons set fire to the entrance door of the offices of the Party of the Socialists of Catalonia (PSC) in Figueres, Spain. The assailants sprinkled flammable liquid over the offices. No one was killed or injured in the attack.
corp1: Party of the Socialists of Catalonia (PSC)
target1: PSC (Party of the Socialists of Catalonia -- Catalan section of the PSOE) offices in Figueres, Spain
motive: Unknown

scite1: “Arson Attack Targets Catalan Socialist Party Offices,” EFE, February 27, 2000.
scite2: “Spanish radio carries further details of Barcelona bomb attacks,” BBC Worldwide Monitoring, March 4, 2000.

summary: 03/04/2000: In a series of related attacks, a bomb exploded at the National Statistics Institute INE office in Barcelona, Spain. The blasts caused major damage, but no one was injured. The device was planted in an entrance next to an elevator. No group claimed responsibility for this incident.
target1: National Statistics Institute INE office in Barcelona, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of gunpowder, batteries and 1.5 kilos of cloratita chlorate-based explosive, made from sulfur, aluminum powder & potassium chlorate.
propcomment: Heavy damage by both bombs was reported.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200003040005-06). There was suspicion that the attacks were related to the March 12, 2000 general election.
scite1: “2 Bombs Explode in Barcelona, Linked to Election,” Madrid RNE-1 Radio, March 4, 2000.
scite2: “Spanish radio carries further details of Barcelona bomb attacks,” Madrid RNE-1 Radio, March 4, 2000.

summary: 03/04/2000: In a series of related attacks, a bomb exploded at the Catalan Socialist Party PSC office in Barcelona, Spain. The blasts caused major damage, but no one was injured. The device was planted in a restroom.  No group claimed responsibility.
target1: Catalan Socialist Party PSC office in Barcelona, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of gunpowder, batteries and 1.5 kilos of cloratita chlorate-based explosive, made from sulfur, aluminum powder & potassium chlorate.
propcomment: Heavy damage by both bombs was reported.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200003040005-06). There was suspicion that the attacks were related to the March 12, 2000 general election.
scite1: “2 Bombs Explode in Barcelona, Linked to Election,” Madrid RNE-1 Radio, March 4, 2000.
scite2: “Spanish radio carries further details of Barcelona bomb attacks,” Madrid RNE-1 Radio, March 4, 2000.

summary: 03/05/2000: Unidentified perpetrators attacked a Commercial Bank branch office in Thessaloniki and hurled at least seven firebombs inside. The subsequent fires destroyed furniture, equipment and an automatic teller machine.
target1: Commercial Bank branch office in Thessaloniki, Greece
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Seven firebombs were used in the attack.
propcomment: Damage from the attack was estimated at about 10 million drachmas.
scite1: “Thessaloniki Bank Attacked With Firebombs,” Athens News Agency, March 5, 2000.

summary: 03/05/2000: A homemade time-bomb exploded outside the offices of ATKOR Construction offices in Athens, Greece. No was injured in the blast. A man who claimed to be with the group Revolutionary Cells (RZ) claimed responsibility for the attack in calls to two Athens newspapers.
target1: Atkor Construction office in Athens, Greece
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Office building was damaged.
scite1: “Revolutionary Cells’ Claim Attack Against Athens Company,” Athens News Agency, March 6, 2000.
scite2: “World In Brief,” The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, March 6, 2000.
scite3: “Bomb blast rocks area north of Athens,” United Press International, March 6, 2000.

location: In the Intxaurrondo neighborhood, in the Basque Country city of San Sebastian
summary: 3/6/2000: A remote-controlled car bomb exploded as an armored Civil Guard patrol car passed by in the Basque country city of San Sebastian, Spain. The explosion blew apart the patrol car, injuring the two members of the Civil Guard who were inside.  At least five additional civilian bystanders were also injured in the explosion.  Members of the ETA, also known as Basque Homeland and Freedom, have been blamed for the attack as an attempt to influence elections.
target1: Members of the Civil Guard traveling in an armored car in San Sebastian
target2: Civilians in the vicinity of a Civil Guard patrol car
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but it is believed that the attack was intended to influence the elections
weapdetail: A remote-controlled car bomb
propcomment: An armored vehicle was destroyed and several surrounding buildings were damaged
addnotes: Sources differ in the number of injured
scite1: "Car-bomb injures seven in Basque city," Associated Press, March 6, 2000.
scite2: "Spain - explosion (3rd lead) seven wounded in Basque region: ETA blamed," EFE News Service, March 6, 2000.
scite3: Adam Brown, "Car-bomb campaign seen unlikely to influence economy-minded voters," Associated Press, March 7, 2000.

summary: 03/11/2000: An explosion caused extensive damage at a tax office in Argentre-du-Plessis (Ille-et-Vilaine), France. An explosive charge consisting of dynamite partially destroyed the ground floor and first floor of the building.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Extensive damage to the office building
addnotes: According to initial investigations, the explosives were part of the same dynamite stolen in Plevin (in Brittany) in September 1999 and used in bomb attacks for which the Breton Revolutionary Army (Breton separatist group) had claimed responsibility. ARB was thought to have been demonstrating its support for a strike by the country's tax officers, which forced the government to postpone the date scheduled for 2000 income tax declarations.
scite1: “Explosive Device Damages Tax Office in Brittany,” France Info Radio, March 11, 2000.
scite2: “ETA Explosives Used in Breton Separatist Attack,” Madrid El Mundo, March 12, 2000.

summary: 03/16/2000: The home of a neighbor of a Popular Party Councilor was firebombed in Getxo, Spain. No one was hurt in the attack. Officials believe that the Councilor's home was the intended target.
target1: Popular Party Councilor's home in Getxo, Spain
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Home Attacked in Basque Country,” Madrid EFE, March 16, 2000.

summary: 03/21/2000: A home-made device exploded at the home of the parents of a 'El Correo' Newspaper journalist in Bilbao, Spain. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: The home of the parents of a 'El Correo' Newspaper journalist in Bilbao, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was composed of several camping gas canisters.
scite1: “Bomb Explodes at Home in Basque Country,” Madrid EFE, March 21, 2000.

summary: 03/25/2000: In a series of related attacks, a bank on Durana Street in Aretxabaleta, Spain, was set on fire in an arson attack that destroyed most of the building.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Series of Arson Attacks Staged in Basque Country,” Madrid EFE, March 25, 2000.

summary: 03/25/2000: In a series of related attacks, a bank on Miracruz Street in San Sebastian, Spain was set on fire in an arson attack that seriously damaged the interior of the building.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Series of Arson Attacks Staged in Basque Country,” Madrid EFE, March 25, 2000.

summary: 03/25/2000: In a series of related attacks, the National Institute of Employment office on San Ignacio Street in Ondarroa, Spain was damaged in an arson attack. Damages were limited to the entrance of the office.
target1: National Institute of Employment office in Ondarroa, Spain
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Series of Arson Attacks Staged in Basque Country,” Madrid EFE, March 25, 2000.

summary: 04/01/2000: A Popular Party Councilor in Santurtzi, Spain, was the target of a firebomb at his home. A number of unidentified perpetrators threw the firebombs at the outside of the house, and they caused little damage.
target1: Popular Party Councilor in Santurtzi, Spain
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used.

summary: 04/01/2000: A Molotov cocktail was thrown at the Total gas station in Dury, France, causing no damage. An anonymous caller claimed responsibility, and claimed to represent ‘an armed group for the protection of the environment,' however a specific group was not identified.
target1: Total gas station in Dury, France
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used.

target2: Domestic Businesses  in a shopping area in Athens, Greece
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Minor damage was done to some of the shops in the area.

summary: 04/03/2000: An Ionian bank branch in the Halandri suburb of Athens, Greece, was destroyed by a bomb blast. Ten gas canisters were wired to a time bomb. No warning was given, as is usual in these cases, and no perpetrators are known.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of ten gas canisters connected to a time bomb.
propcomment: The branch office was completely destroyed.

summary: 04/03/2000: A Commercial Bank branch in the Halandri suburb of Athens, Athens prefecture, Greece, was destroyed by a bomb blast. There was no warning and the perpetrators are unknown. The bomb consisted of ten gas canisters connected to a time bomb.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of ten gas canisters connected to a time bomb.
propcomment: The branch office was completely destroyed.

location: Londonderry (County)
summary: 04/06/2000: A British Army camp in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, was the target of a bomb attack by suspected members of the Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA). A guardhouse was damaged, but no one was injured. Two unidentified men were seen fleeing the scene.
target1: British Army camp in Londonderry, Northern Ireland
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Five pounds of homemade explosives were used.
propcomment: A guardhouse was damaged.
scite1: “Blast Damages Northern Ireland army camp,” United Press International, April 6, 2000.
scite2: Hayes, Dominic, “Security Review After Bomb Attack,” Press Association, April 6, 2000.
scite3: Cowan, Rosie,“Bomb Brings Warning of Dissident Terror Wave,” Press Association, April 6, 2000.

summary: 04/12/2000: A previously unknown anarchist group, Last Generation, claimed responsibility for the firebombing of two cars in Zografou, Greece. The cars were severely damaged, but there were no injuries.
target1: Two private cars in Zografou, Greece
motive: The attack was seen as a response to the death of a Greek immigrant from Georgia who was in police custody.
propcomment: The cars suffered severe damage.
scite1: “Anarchist Greek Group Claims Responsibility for Car Bomb,” Athens News, April 13, 2000.

location: Fermanagh (County)
summary: 04/13/2000: The Continuity IRA claimed responsibility for an attempted attack on the Royal Ulster Constabulary base at Rosslea, County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland. The claim was made in a phone call to a newspaper in Belfast. The perpetrators attempted to launch a mortar at the base, but the device exploded in the back of the car which was being used to launch the shell. No one was hurt in the attack.
target1: Royal Ulster Constabulary base in Rosslea, Northern Ireland
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The perpetrators attempted to use a mortar mounted on a car.
scite1: Henderson, Deric, “Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA)Blamed For Failed Bomb Attack,” Press Association, April 13, 2000.
scite2: Graham, Ian, “Dissidents Behind Failed Mortar Attack,” Press Association, April 14, 2000.

summary: 04/15/2000: A bomb attack badly damaged a former police station in Lecumberry, France. The device was a gas cylinder bomb weighing about 13kg. The Basque group Iparretarrak (IK) claimed responsibility through a statement sent to the Agence France Presse.
target1: Former police station in Lecumberry, France
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of a gas cylinder weighing 13kg.
propcomment: The police station was badly damaged.
scite1: “France: Bomb Attack Believed Committed By Basque IK,” AFP (Domestic Service), April 15, 2000.
scite2: “French Basque Group Claims Responsibility for Bomb Attack,” AFP (Domestic Service), April 19, 2000.

summary: 04/15/2000: The discotheque “Amnesia” in Bonifacio, France, was the target of a bomb attack. The attack caused major damage to the building, but no one was injured. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The club sustained major damage.
scite1: “France: Explosive Attack on Discotheque in Corsica,” AFP (Domestic Service), April 16, 2000.

summary: 04/19/2000: A bomb exploded at a McDonald’s fast food restaurant in Quevert, Brittany, France. One person was killed, and caused major damage to the building. Police have linked the bombing to the Breton Revolutionary Army (ARB).
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was made with dynamite.
propcomment: Major damage to the roof and drive-in area of the restaurant.
scite1: “Bomb attack on McDonald’s kills one, police suspect Breton nationalists,” Agence France Presse, April 19, 2000.
scite2: “McDonald’s Blast Kills 1 in France,” Associated Press, April 19, 2000.

summary: 04/21/2000: The Basilica of the Holy House in Loreto, Italy, was the target of a failed bomb attack by a group calling themselves the Iconoclasts. The device consisted of two plastic bags of gasoline and over one hundred matches with a delayed fuse. The group claimed responsibility in a letter to the ANSA news agency.
target1: The Basilica of the Holy House in Loreto, Italy
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was made of two plastic bags containing gasoline, over one hundred matches and a delay time fuse. The fuse was blown out by wind.
scite1: “Terror Bomb Targets Catholic Shrine,” ANSA, April 21, 2000.

summary: 04/21/2000: The Credit Agricole bank in Sagone, France, was the target of a explosive charge connected to a gas cylinder. The building was badly damaged, but no one was injured, as the attack occurred at night.
target1: Credit Agricole Bank in Sagone, Corsica
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was made up of an explosive charge attached to a gas cylinder.
propcomment: The bank was severely a damaged by the bomb blast.
scite1: “France: Corsican Bank Badly Damaged in Bomb Blast,” France Info Radio, April 22, 2000.

summary: 04/25/2000: Journalist Jesus Maria Zuloaga of the newspaper La Razon was the target of a mail bomb sent by suspected Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA). The bomb was sent to the La Razon offices in Madrid, Spain. The device consisted of a hollowed out copy of “Crime and Punishment” which contained a bottle of beauty lotion with between 100 and 150 grams of an explosive substance. The device was destroyed in a controlled explosion by police.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device consisted of a hollowed out copy of "Crime and Punishment, with 100-150 grams of explosive material contained in a beauty lotion bottle.
scite1: “Parcel bomb was from Basque terrorists says interior minister,” Agence France Presse, April 25, 2000.

location: The home of the intelligence coordinator in Bern
summary: 4/25/2000: Members of the Revolutionary Perspective detonated a small bomb at the home of the intelligence coordinator, Jacques Pitteloud, in Bern, Switzerland.  No one was injured, but the explosion caused minor damage to the building.  The assailants sent a letter to the police stating that the attack was in response to a Swiss Army exhibition opening in Basel the same week.  The attack was paired with another bombing that happened at the offices of the defense minister in Bern.
target1: Jacques Pitteloud, the Swiss intelligence coordinator
motive: The assailants sent a letter to the police stating that the attack was in response to a Swiss Army exhibition opening in Basel the same week.
propcomment: Minor damage to the building
scite1: "Swiss police investigate into bomb attacks in Bern," Xinhua News Agency, April 25, 2000.
scite2: "Anti-militarists set off two bombs in Berne," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, April 25, 2000.

location: J's, a discotheque in the St.Pauli red-light district in Hamburg
summary: 4/29/2000: A Yugoslav-made hand grenade exploded in a discotheque in Hamburg, Germany.  Approximately 1500 people were in the disco at the time of the explosion, but only nine people were wounded; two were seriously wounded.  A week later, a man who had been identified by photographs was arrested in connection to the bombing.  There is speculation that the bombing may have been related to a battle over territory.
target1: Civilians at a discotheque in Hamburg
motive: Specific motive is unknown but authorities speculate that the incident may have been related to turf wars
weapdetail: A Yugoslav-made hand grenade
propcomment: A grenade went off in a crowded discotheque
addnotes: One source states that eight people were injured while two state that nine people were injured
scite1: "Nine injured after hand grenade explodes in Hamburg disco," Associated Press, April 29, 2000.
scite2: "Germany - bomb eight injured when hand grenade explodes inside German disco," EFE News Service, April 29, 2000.
scite3: "Suspect arrested over Hamburg disco grenade attack," Reuters, May 7, 2000.

location: Tyrone (County)
summary: 05/02/2000: Members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army attacked Paul Macdonald on the night of May 2, 2000. He was beaten and then shot in front of his girlfriend in their home in Dungannon located in the Northern Ireland county of Tyrone. He survived the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: It is probable that there was damage done to the home when the assailants broke in.
scite1: Suzanne Breen,"IRA Believed to Have Brutally Beaten, Shot Father," The Irish Times, May 3, 2000.
scite2: John Mullin, “Paramilitary Cold War Hots Up," The Guardian, May 3, 2000.

summary: 05/03/2000: On the morning of May 3, 2000 a bomb was set off in Paris, France. The Crazy Horse cabaret was the target. There was property damage but no injuries. It is unknown who was responsible for this act. It was linked to two other casino bombings that night: one in Juan-les-Pins and the other in Carry-le-Roulet.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: There was damage to the exterior of the cabaret.
scite1: Susan Bell, "Bombs Target French Cabaret and Casinos," Agence France Presse, May 4, 2000.
scite2: France: Bomb Attacks Damage Two Casinos in Southwest,"  France Info Radio, May 3, 2000.

summary: 05/03/2000: On the morning of May 3, 2000 a bomb was set off in Juan-les-Pins, France. An unnamed casino was the target. There was property damage but no injuries. It is unknown who was responsible for this act. It was linked to two other bombings that night: a cabaret in Paris and another casino in Carry-le-Roulet.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: There was damage to the exterior of the casino
scite1: Susan Bell, "Bombs Target French Cabaret and Casinos," Agence France Presse, May 4, 2000.

summary: 05/07/2000: Journalist Jose Luis Lopez de La Calle was shot dead outside his home in Andoain, Spain. The attack was perpetrated by the Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA).
target1: Jose Luis Lopez de La Calle
motive: The motivation behind this attack was to send a message to the Media. The group sent the message that they did not appreciate their portrayal in the press.
addnotes: Arnaldo Otegi, the Leader of the Nationalist Euskal Herritarrok Party accepted responsibility for the ETA. This party is a political ally of the group. This attack also led to protests across Spain. The Royal Family participated in these protests.
scite1: "Journalist’s Murder Sparks Mass Anti-Terrorist Protest Across Spain,"  Agence France Presse, May 8, 2000.
scite2: “Shooting of Journalist Linked to Basque Terrorist Group ETA," The Associated Presse, May 8, 2000.
scite3: Mar Roman, “Journalist who was Critical of ETA Shot Dead in the Basque Region," The Associated Press, May 7, 2000.

summary: 05/08/2000: An armored security van was attacked in Vigo in Northern Spain. The October 1 Anti-Fascist Resistance Group (GRAPO) was believed to be responsible. After the bomb exploded, the group opened fire killing two and injuring four.
target1: Armored vehicle of a Spanish company
gname: First of October Antifascist Resistance Group (GRAPO)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The van involved in the attack was damaged.
scite1: "Extreme-Left Group Behind Attack on Spanish Armoured Van: Prefect," Agence France Presse, May 12, 2000.
scite2: “Spanish Police Link Urban Guerrillas to Armed Robbery in Vigo," Barcelona La Vanguardia, May 9, 2000.
scite3: “French Report on Terrorism," French Government, May 14, 2000.

summary: 05/20/2000: An attempted attack on the Societe Nationale Corse-Mediterranee (SNCM) Ferry Company main office building in Marseille, France, was foiled when security guards found a container with 20 liters of solid nitrate with a timer detonator. The device was deactivated prior to causing any damage. There was no claim of responsibility for the incident.
target1: SNCM Main Office Building in Marseille
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb used in this incident was comprised of 20 liters of solid nitrate with a timer detonator.
addnotes: The incident occurred just hours after SNCM staff voted to end a five-day strike.
scite1: "France: Explosive Attack on Corsica Ferry Company Foiled," France Info Radio, May 21, 2000.
scite2: Andrew Spurrier, "Marseille: SNCM Attempt Foiled After Strike Action was Resolved," Lloyd's List, May 22, 2000.

location: Oxfordshire (County)
summary: 05/21/2000: An incendiary device at the Mutchmeats Limited meat packing plant in Witney, Oxfordshire county, United Kingdom, ignited a refrigeration truck but resulted in no casualties. Nine similar devices attached to vehicles at the plant were safely deactivated before causing any additional damage. Authorities suspected that the Animal Liberation Front (ALF) was behind the incident.
target1: Vehicles Located at a Mutchmeats Limited Meat Packing Plant in Witney
motive: Unknown

summary: 06/01/2000: Members of the Continuity Irish Republican Army (CIRA) bombed the Hammersmith bridge in London in order to destabilize the political process in Northern Ireland. No casualties resulted from the incident.

summary: 06/03/2000: Three unknown masked individuals set fire to a branch of the Guipuzcoa provincial tax office in Renteria, Spain, after evacuating the premises. No casualties resulted from the incident.

motive: Unknown

location: Belfast (Capital City)

location: This incident occurred in the northern suburbs of Athens.

addnotes: This was one of four related incidents (cf. 200006080010, 200006080011, and 200006080012). Historically GRAPO targeted temporary employment agencies because it saw them as agents of capitalist exploitation.

location: Londonderry (County)
summary: 06/17/2000: Shots were fired by an unknown source at the house of Helen Wray in Londonderry, Belfast in Northern Ireland. No casualties resulted from the attack. This house had been the site of previous paramilitary attacks.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Attackers fired at a private residence.
addnotes: Helen Wray believed that fellow Protestants were to blame for the attack. However, police did not believe that the incident was linked to the Loyalist feud that had been occurring at the time. Furthermore, the police did not believe the attack was an incidence of sectarian violence.
scite1: “Protestants Blamed for Gun Attack,” Century Newspapers Limited, June 17, 2000.

location: Ulster. In a park near Hillsborough Castle outside of Belfast
summary: 6/19/2000: An explosive device was discovered in a park near Hillsborough Castle outside of Belfast, in County Antrim, Northern Ireland.  Hillsborough Castle is the official residence of the Queen, but Britain's minister for Northern Ireland, Peter Mandelson, was the current resident.  The device had partially exploded when it was found.  Authorities blame Republican dissidents for the attempted attack.
target1: Peter Mandelson, Britain's minister for Northern Ireland
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An explosive device that partially exploded
scite1: Nicholas Watt and Maggie O'Kane, "Loyalists warned over ceasefire threat," The Guardian, June 21, 2000.
scite2: Maggie O'Kane and Nicholas Watt, "Belfast blast increases tensions," The Guardian, June 22, 2000.
scite3: "Explosive device found near British minister's residence," Agence France-Presse, June 20, 2000.

location: Belfast (Capital City)
summary: 06/21/2000: A bomb exploded at the back of a terrace house in the predominately Catholic Balymurphy district in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The blast injured a Catholic man and his son. The Protestant loyalists, the Ulster Freedom Fighters were suspected to be connected with the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A bomb exploded on the back of a terrace of a house.

location: Ballymurphy (County)
summary: 06/21/2000: A Catholic man was attacked by eight masked men in Londonderry, Belfast in Northern Ireland. The attackers broke his arms and legs with iron bars. Although the assailants were unknown, the attack occurred after Protestant militants threatened to end a ceasefire.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The attackers used iron bars.
scite1: “Arrest made after Belfast blast hurts Catholic man, son,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, June 21, 2000.

weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in this attack.
propcomment: Serious damage was caused to the banks.

motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in this attack.
propcomment: Serious damage was caused to the banks.

location: The Las Arenas quarter of Getxo, in the northern Basque region, Spain
summary: 6/25/2000: Individuals claiming to be from the Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA) detonated a car bomb in the Las Arenas quarter of Getxo, in the northern Basque region, Spain.  Police received a tip from the assailants in advance of the explosion and managed to close off the street before the explosion.  At least four people were injured in the attack and the street and surrounding cars suffered damage.  Sources believed that the attack was intended to intimidate business people living in the area to pay a ransom or "revolutionary tax" to the ETA.  It is possible the assailants were targeting one family, the Delclaux, who had failed to pay full ransom for their son.
target1: Civilians in the Las Arenas quarter of Getxo
motive: The assailants stated that the attack was intended for the oligarchy.  Sources believed that the attack was intended to intimidate business people living in the area to pay a ransom or "revolutionary tax" to the ETA.  It is possible the assailants were targeting one family, the Delclaux, who had failed to pay full ransom for their son.
weapdetail: The car bomb was placed in a white Mercedes
propcomment: The bomb caused a crater in the street, destroyed vehicles and shattered building windows
addnotes: Sources differ in the number injured; one source states that four people were injured and one source states that five were injured.  There is also conflicting information concerning the target; the government claims that the targets were business people living in the area while media sources state that the target was a particular family.
scite1: "Car bomb injures four in Spain's Basque region," Dow Jones International News, June 24, 2000.
scite2: "Several injured as car bomb explodes in northern Spain," Agence France-Presse, June 25, 2000.
scite3: "Report: car bomb aimed at scaring wealthy Basque family," Associated Press, June 26, 2000.

summary: 06/25/2000: An insurance office in Renteria, Guipuzcoa Province, suffered an arson attack by an unknown group. The building sustained minimal damage during the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The entrance to an insurance building suffered damage due to arson.
scite1: “Spain: Insurance Office Targeted in Arson Attack in Basque Town,” Madrid EFE, June 26, 2000.

location: In the vicinity of the International Conference Center near the Arc de Triomphe in central Paris
summary: 6/26/2000: Workers found a bomb in the vicinity of the Kleber Center, a government conference center, near the Arc de Triomphe in central Paris, France.  The bomb consisted of 23 sticks of dynamite, an alarm clock, and two detonators; the batteries failed, so the bomb did not detonate.  A Corsican separatist group, the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC), claimed responsibility for the failed attack and stated that the bomb was supposed to explode early Monday.  The FLNC stated that the French government was responsibly for a policy of eradication of their community.
target1: The Kleber Center, a government conference center
target2: Civilians in the vicinity of the Kleber Center and a construction site
motive: The perpetrators stated that they were provoked by a police on the part of the French government to eradicate the Corsican community

scite2: "Bomb found near Paris conference centre," Reuters, June 26, 2000.
scite3: "Corsican separatists say they were behind Paris bomb," Agence France-Presse, June 27, 2000.

summary: 06/28/2000: An incendiary device was discovered in a confessional in the basilica of Sant’Ambrogio in Milan, Italy. Its presence was indicated in a document sent to the offices of Rome daily il Messaggero by the anarchical movement known as International Solidarity.
motive: Group was demanding the release of jailed comrades.
weapdetail: The weapon consisted of two incendiary bottles with a chemical fuse powered by electric batteries.
scite1: “Incendiary Device Discovered in Milan Church,” Rome RAI Television Teletext, June 29, 2000.

location: Belfast (Capital City)
summary: 06/30/2000: An Irish Republican Army member fired an automatic weapon at a four-man loyalist gang rampaging across the St. James area of Belfast in Northern Ireland. No one was harmed in the attack.
target1: Northern Irish men belonging to a Loyalist group
motive: The attacker was angered by the presence of loyalists in an Irish Republican Army controlled neighborhood.
scite1: “Belfast: Lone IRA Gunman Routs Loyalist Gang,” Belfast Andersonstown News, June 30, 2000.

summary: 06/30/2000: A homemade device exploded in Conde don Vela Street next to a Telefonica vehicle in Vitoria-Gasteiz, Spain. The blast resulted in vehicular damage but there were no casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but Basque separatists were suspected.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A Telefonica company vehicle was damaged in the attack.
scite1: “Vitoria-Gasteiz Blast ‘Several Hundred’ Meters From Government Building,” Madrid EFE, June 30, 2000.

location: Down (County). This incident occurred three miles outside of Newry.
summary: 06/30/2000: An explosive device detonated either on or near the railroad tracks of the main Belfast-Dublin line, three miles outside Newry, Northern Ireland. The railway train was halted for the day as authorities examined the damaged track. The attack was blamed on dissident republicans who opposed the peace process in Northern Ireland. No one was killed or injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The rail line was damaged in the attack.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: The incident occurred at the Lettereev area of Ballymena.
summary: 7/17/2000: Unidentified assailants threw a petrol bomb at a house in the Lettereev area of Ballymena, County Antrim, Northern Ireland.  The explosive device did not ignite and the house was not damaged.  Sources report that the house belonged to a Catholic and authorities suspect that it was a sectarian attack instigated by Protestants.
target1: The home of a Catholic person in County Antrim
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources are calling the incident sectarian violence between Protestants and Catholics
weapdetail: A petrol bomb that did not ignite
scite1: "Mayor blasts wave of fire attacks," Belfast News Letter, July 20, 2000.
scite2: Monika Unsworth, "Arson attack on Ballymena school widely condemned," Irish Times, July 20, 2000.
scite3: "Anti-Catholic protests rekindled in Ballymena," Irish Times, July 24, 2000.

summary: 07/05/2000: Turkey's consulate general in Rhodes, Dodecanese Prefecture, was attacked by Molotov cocktails, resulting in minor damage to the building. No casualties were reported from the incident.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
propcomment: There was minor damage to the consulate general building as a result of the incident.
scite1: “One Line: Fire Bomb Attack on Turkish consulate General in Rhodes,” Turkish Daily News, July 6, 2000.
scite2: “Turkey Condemns Bomb Attack on Turkish Consulate General in Rhodes,” Ankara Anatolia, July 5, 2000.
scite3: “Bomb Attack on Turkish Consulate in Rhodes Causes Minor Damage,” Ankara Anatolia, July 5, 2000.

location: Northern Ireland (State)
summary: 07/05/2000:  Officers in the Royal Ulster Constabulary were squirted with acid caustics in Drumcree, Northern Ireland.  Seven people were injured in the attack.
target1: Officers of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.
motive: To protest the cancellation of the Drumcree 2000 march.
weapdetail: Acidic caustic
scite1: "Police Attacked with Acid and Stone," The Royal Ulster Constabulary website, July 7, 2000.
scite2: Jamie Macaskill, "Streets of Fear as Ulster Faces Breaking Point; Drumcree Crisis: RUC Struggle to Cope with Violence," Scottish Daily Record, July 6, 2000.

summary: 07/06/2000: The self-styled Revolutionary Proletarian Initiative Nuclei (NIPR) planted two firebombs outside of a Milan trade union office. The bombs were discovered and defused before causing any damage or casualties. The NIPR claimed responsibility for the incident in a letter.
corp1: CISL Italian Confederation of Trade Unions
target1: Milan office of the CISL trade union
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bombs utilized were bags of explosives placed in flower pots with wiring visible and connected to a timer.
addnotes: This may have been the first attack claimed by the Revolutionary Proletarian Initiative Nuclei (NIPR).
scite1: “Firebombs found outside trade union offices in Milan,” Agence France Presse, July 6, 2000.
scite2: “Firebombs found outside union offices,” ANSA News Agency, July 6, 2000.

summary: 07/06/2000: A 79 year-old man was critically injured by a pipe bomb he found on a beach in Lignano, Italy. It was unknown who was responsible for the incident.
target1: Indiscriminate tourists on a Lignano beach
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb used in the attack was an 8 inch long pipe, similar to that used between 1994-1996 in the same area.
addnotes: One source claimed that this incident is loosely linked with bombs planted in Milan by the NIPR (cf. 200007060001). Other sources see no such connection, and speculate connections to the Unabomber or the "Beach Bomber" from the mid-90s.
scite1: “Pipe bomb wounds 79-year-old man,” Associated Press Worldstream, July 7, 2000.
scite2: John Phillips, “Pipe bomber sows fear on Italian beaches,” The Times (London), July 8, 2000.

location: Tyrone (County)
summary: 07/09/2000: A car bomb exploded outside of a police station in Stewartstown, Northern Ireland, hours before the country's more contentious Protestant parade. Police believed that dissidents from the Irish Republican Army (IRA) were opposed to the peace process. No casualties were reported from the incident.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was used in the attack.
propcomment: Windows of the police station were damaged and a gasoline station nearby was badly damaged as a result of the incident.
scite1: "Car bomb explodes outside N Ireland police station,” Agence France Presse, July 9, 2000.
scite2: Shawn Pogatchnik, “Car bomb blasts police station in Catholic town before march,” The Associated Press, July 9, 2000.

summary: 07/12/2000: The Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) exploded a huge car bomb exploded in the heart of Madrid's main shopping district, injuring eight people. The ETA claimed responsibility for the attack in a pre-incident phone call.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians in Madrid's main shopping district
motive: The ETA wanted to prove its capabilities to carry out an attack and to fracture a planned relationship between the Spanish government and Basque authorities.
weapdetail: The attack was carried out by 15 kg of explosives that were packed in a vehicle and set to explode at a specific time by a timer.
propcomment: The car was destroyed as a result of the incident.
addnotes: ETA called the police threatening that a bomb would explode in 30 minutes, but it instead exploded 15 minutes after the call. This is a common tactic used by ETA, and may be intended to kill police responding to the threat.
scite1: Adela Gooch, “ETA bombs Madrid: Eight hurt in early morning blast,” The Guardian (London), July 13, 2000.
scite2: “Car bomb injures 9 in central Madrid,” The New York Times News Service, July 13, 2000.

location: Pamplona, Navarre
summary: 7/13/2000: Unidentified assailants threw an improvised explosive device (IED) at the home of Jose Cruz Perez Lapazaran in Pamplona, Navarre province, Spain.  Lapazaran is a Spanish MP and vice-president of Union of the Navarrese People (UPN).  Lapazaran and his family were out of town on vacation at the time of the incident.  No one was harmed and the attack caused only minor damage.  Lapazaran is opposed to independence for the Basque region.
target1: Jose Cruz Perez Lapazaran, MP and vice-president of Union of the Navarrese People (UPN)
motive: Specific motive is unknown but Jose Cruz Perez Lapazaran is opposed to independence for the Basque region
weapdetail: A homemade bomb
propcomment: The bomb caused "minor" damage
addnotes: No specific group is mentioned but sources speculate that the incident was caused by Basque separatists
scite1: "Explosion targets Spanish deputy's home," Agence France-Presse, July 13, 2000.
scite2: "Small bomb hurled at doorstep of anti-independence politician," Associated Press, July 13, 2000.
scite3: "Bomb explodes at Spanish MP's home," EFE News Service, July 13, 2000.

location: County Antrim. The Catholic chapel of Our Lady in Harryville district, Ballymena
summary: 7/17/2000: Arsonists attempted to burn down the Catholic chapel of Our Lady in Harryville district, Ballymena, County Antrim, Northern Ireland.  The arsonists cut through the security grill, piled up carpets and altar cloths, and started a fire.  The fire burnt out before considerable damage could be inflicted on the chapel.  Local authorities have labeled it a sectarian attack and are blaming Protestants for the fire.

motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources are calling the incident sectarian violence between Protestants and Catholics

location: Ealing (Borough)
summary: 07/19/2000: The Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA) was held responsible for planting a bomb at Ealing Broadway Tube Station, London, on the Queen Mother’s birthday. After receiving a tip-off, police discovered the bomb before it exploded.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: A coded call was received by the government and the bomb found, removed, and safely detonated.

weapdetail: A car bomb was used in the attack.

propcomment: Three windows were broken and the curtains were set on fire.  The building suffered smoke and water damage.

summary: 07/20/2000: A car bomb was found and safely defused by police in Malaga, Spain. An anonymous caller warned firefighters of the bomb and stated that it had been planted in the name of Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA). Reportedly, the car had been prepared to explode upon a careless search of the vehicle.
target1: Responders to the Report of the Car Bomb
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was used in the attack.
addnotes: An anonymous call was made to the Malaga fire service claiming responsibility for the bomb. Police presume that the bomb was meant to detonate upon careless defusing by the fire service.

scite3: “Spain: Explosive Device Deactivated in Car in Malaga,” Madrid EFE, July 20, 2000.

summary: 07/24/2000: Four people were injured as a result of a car bomb exploded outside the house of a Popular Party politician, Senator Pilar Aresti, in Getxo, Spain. A caller claimed responsibility for the bombing, stating he was from the Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA).

summary: 07/26/2000: The offices of the Caja Vital bank in Vitoria-Gasteiz, Spain, were damaged when an a bomb set by Euskadi Ta Askatasuna (ETA) exploded. A member of the ETA called local newspapers and gave a ten minute warning that the bomb would explode near the bank office. No casualties resulted from the incident.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The incident resulted in damage to the bank office building.

scite1: "Bomb explosion damages bank office in Vitoria-Gasteiz,” The Associated Press, July 27, 2000.

summary: 07/26/2000: A bomb set under a car owned by a Popular Party candidate, Agustin Ramos Vallejo, was found and destroyed by authorities in Durango, Spain. The police-led controlled explosion destroyed the car and damaged other vehicles parked in the surroundings. Authorities suspected that Euskadi Ta Askatasuna (ETA) members were responsible for the incident.

summary: 07/27/2000: Nine people were injured after the explosion of a splinter bomb planted by suspected right-wing, neo-Nazi extremists at rail station in Dusseldorf, Germany. All nine casualties were foreign students, to include six Russian and Ukrainian Jews.

target2: Foreign students in the train station
motive: Unknown

location: The incident occurred at a branch of EFG Eurobank.
summary: 7/29/2000: An improvised explosive device (IED) blew up outside of a branch of EFG Eurobank in downtown Athens, Greece.  The explosion caused minor damage to the bank, including to the automated teller machine and the front entrance.  The bomb consisted of several gas canisters and containers of petrol.  A note left at the scene stated that the attack was in response to "government attempts to deregulate the labor market".
target1: An Athens branch of EFG Eurobank
motive: A note was left at the scene stating that the attack was in response to "government attempts to deregulate the labor market"
weapdetail: The bomb was made up of six gas canisters and two petrol containers
propcomment: An automated teller machine was damaged, as was the front entrance to the bank
scite1: "Greek anarchists claim gas bomb attack on bank," Reuters, July 29, 2000.

propcomment: The incident resulted in damage to the front door of the building.

scite2: Lucian Kim, “GERMANY CONFRONTS RISING TIDE OF RACISM AS NEW IMMIGRANTS ARRIVE,” The Independent, August 1, 2000.

motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources speculate that the attack may have been in response to the failing stock market

propcomment: A car exploded

summary: 8/2/2000: A bomb exploded in the lobby of Sharelink, a stock company, in Paralimni, Cyprus.  No one was injured in the attack but the lobby was badly damaged.  There is speculation that the bombing may have been in response to a failing stock market.

weapdetail: A bomb planted in a lobby
propcomment: A bomb exploded in an office lobby

summary: 08/07/2000: A remote-control car-bomb triggered by suspected Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) members killed Mr. Jose Maria Korta as he parked outside the Korta Plant, his company's office in the Industrial Estate in Zumaia, Spain. The police was informed of this attack however were unable to respond in time.

motive: To assassinate a Basque businessman who criticized ETA.

Mr. Korta, a machine-tool manufacturer, was president of the employers' association of Guipuzcoa, the Basque province where ETA's roots were strongest.

It is still unclear whether the car was a car-bomb being driven to its target or whether the ETA members were simply moving material elsewhere.

location: Le Piscine bar in L'Ile-Rousse, upper Corsica
summary: 8/7/2000: Five unidentified assailants opened fire in a targeted attack on Le Piscine bar in L'Ile-Rousse, upper Corsica, France.  Jean-Michel Rossi and his bodyguard, Jean-Claude Fratacci, were shot dead in the attack and a bartender was injured.  Rossi was former member of Corsica's nationalist Cuncolta Naziunalista party and the right hand of it's leader, Francois Santoni.  Rossi and Santoni had just published a book that denounced the party.  Authorities are not certain whether the attack was politically motivated or instigated by the criminal underworld.
target1: Jean-Michel Rossi and his bodyguard, Jean-Claude Fratacci, as well as a bartender
motive: Specific motive is unknown but authorities speculate that the attack was ordered by terrorists or the criminal underworld.  The victim had just published a controversial book that denounced an organization.
weapdetail: Machine guns
addnotes: Sources speculate that the attack may have been a criminal underworld killing and, therefore, not a terrorist event.  However, this has not been confirmed.

scite2: "Noted Corsican nationalist killed in gunfight," Associated Press, August 7, 2000.

location: A building located on Lanomendi Street, in Getxo near Bilbao
summary: 8/14/2000: An improvised explosive device (IED) consisting of a camping gas canister exploded on Lanomendi Street, in Getxo, Basque country, Spain.  No one was injured in the attack but the façade of a building was damaged.  Sources indicate that the attack was perpetrated by youth close to the group Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA).

motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An improvised explosive device (IED) consisting of a camping gas canister
propcomment: The façade of a building was damaged in the explosion

location: Ondorroa town
summary: 8/14/2000:  A bus driver was forced off his bus by a group of hooded youths in Ondorroa, Biscay province, Spain.  The assailants then lit the bus on fire using fire bombs.  Three other vehicles parked nearby were damaged in the incident.  The youth were close to the group Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA).  The motive is not known.
target2: Vehicles parked within the vicinity of the bus
motive: Unknown

propcomment: A bus and three other vehicles were damaged in the blaze
addnotes: The motive behind the attack is unknown

location: In Navarra province in Basque country
summary: 8/14/2000:  Youths burned a car belonging to a politician in Navarra province, Basque country, Spain.  The politician was a member of the right-wing Popular Party.  The youths were close to the group Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA).  No one was injured in the attack.
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but the politician was a member of the right-wing Popular Party
weapdetail: Fire
propcomment: A car was burned
addnotes: The motive behind the attack is unknown
scite1: "Urban guerrilla attacks continue in Basque country," Agence France-Presse, August 14, 2000.

location: County Antrim. The Oldpark area of north Belfast
summary: 8/15/2000: Suspected republicans threw a pipe bomb at Johnny Adair in North Belfast, County Antrim, Northern Ireland.  "Mad Dog" Adair was a former Protestant loyalist leader who had recently completed a 16 year sentence for directing terrorism.  Adair had just parked his car in a Protestant area of North Belfast when unknown assailants threw a pipe bomb at his car, shattering the windshield.  Adair suffered minor cuts and bruises but was otherwise unharmed.  Authorities claim that the pipe bomb construction was a traditional method for loyalists but Adiar insisted that the attack was orchestrated by republican paramilitaries.
target1: "Mad Dog" Johnny Adair, former Protestant leader of loyalist extremists
target2: Civilians in the vicinity of the Adair's car
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but the victim speculates that it was an attempt to provoke a reaction from the loyalists and create instability
weapdetail: A pipe bomb
propcomment: A pipe bomb was thrown at a car, shattering the windshield and causing damage
addnotes: The victim claims the attack was perpetrated by republicans while the authorities claim that the pipe bomb indicates that it was an attack by the loyalists
scite1: "N.Ireland loyalist leader survives murder attempt," Agence France-Presse, August 15, 2000.
scite2: "Update 1 - bomb attack in Belfast raises sectarian tensions," Reuters, August 15, 2000.
scite3: David McKittrick, "Loyalist leader Adair survives pipe bomb attack," The Independent, August 16, 2000.

summary: 08/16/2000: A car belonging to Italian Embassy Attache, Tasi Antonela, parked outside her residence in Vouliagmeni, Greece, and was set on fire by the so-called Mavro Asteri (Black Star) anarchist group. No one was injured as a result of the attack.
target1: Car belonging to Italian Attache in Greece, Tasi Antonela
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Gasoline was poured over the car and set on fire.
propcomment: The targeted car was set on fire and destroyed along with a moped.
addnotes: An unidentified person called "Elevtherotipia" and took responsibility for the attack in the name of the anarchist organization Mavro Asteri (Black Star) and added: "Freedom to Simeon Sisidhi". The latter was a youth who had been recently arrested for various criminal acts.
scite1: “Greek organization ‘Black Star’ claims attack on Italian diplomat car in Athens,” Elevtherotipia, August 18, 2000.
scite2: “Greece: Italian diplomat's car set alight, anarchists' said to claim responsibility,” BBC Worldwide Monitoring, August 17, 2000.
scite3: “Greek terrorists set fire to Italian Embassy worker’s car,” ANSA, August 17, 2000.

summary: 08/17/2000: A rocket with an inert charge was fired at a government building in Sartene in southern Corsica, France. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but local authorities blamed armed militants within the highly fragmented Corsican nationalist movement. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: The private living quarters of the sub-prefect of Sartene
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The rocket launcher was a Soviet manufactured RPG-7.
propcomment: The explosion damaged part of the balcony of the apartment occupied by the sub-prefect and his family.    The blast broke several of the building's windows.
addnotes: The detained perpetrator was suspected by the authorities to be associated with the Armata Corsa clandestine group.
scite1: Robert Graham, “Corsican rocket attack blamed on nationalists,” Financial Times, August 18, 2000.
scite2: Adam Sage, “Rocket hits Corsican building,” The Gazette, August 18, 2000.
scite3: “Le Monde on suspect confession to Corsica rocket attack,” Le Monde, August 22, 2000.

location: The incident occurred at a hostel.
summary: 8/20/2000: Unidentified assailants threw a smoke bomb into a hostel in Eisenhuettenstadt, Germany.  The hostel was housing Colombian asylum seekers.  Seven people suffered eye injuries as a result of the attack and the apartment walls were damaged by the smoke.  Authorities believe that the attack was perpetrated by neo-Nazis.
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources state that it was xenophobic incident
weapdetail: A smoke bomb
propcomment: The walls of an apartment were damaged by smoke
scite1: "Smoke bomb attack against asylum seekers' home in Germany," Agence France-Presse, August 20, 2000.
scite2: "More xenophobic, Neo-Nazi actions reported in Brandenburg," Berlin DPP, August 20, 2000.

summary: 08/20/2000: Two Spanish Civil Guard police officers were killed in northern Spain when a bomb blew up their patrol car. Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) was blamed for the attack.
target1: Two Civil Guard police officers in the town of Sallent de Gallego in Huesca Province
motive: ETA was trying to turn public opinion against the government's hard-line stance towards the separatists.
weapdetail: The bomb had been placed in a patrol car, a Jeep, to the vehicle's underside.
propcomment: The Jeep was completely destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: According to the interior minister, ETA was trying to respond to police actions against their organization.
scite1: “Two police die as ETA bombs blows up patrol vehicle,” Birmingham Post, August 21, 2000.
scite2: “Two Spanish police officers killed in suspected ETA bombing attack,” Xinhua General News Service, August 20, 2000.
scite3: “Spanish Interior Minister says Civil Guards killed by cross-border ETA commando,” Madrid EFE, August 20, 2000.

location: County Antrim. Along Crumlin Road in north Belfast
summary: 8/21/2000: Two men were killed in a shooting outside of a betting shop in north Belfast, Northern Ireland.  The two victims, Jackie Coulter and Bobby Mahood, were shot while sitting in a vehicle; Coulter died immediately and Mahood died later in the hospital.  Both victims had ties to the Ulster Freedom Fighters (UFF).  Sources believe that the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) is responsible for the attack and that it was in retaliation for UFF-instigated attacks on UVF supporters.
motive: Specific motive is unknown but sources believe that the attack was retaliatory
addnotes: Mahood was once a UVF member and Coulter was an active UDA member.
scite1: "Ulster - shooting one dead and one wounded in North Belfast drive-by shooting," EFE News Service, August 21, 2000.
scite2: "World briefs," Houston Chronicle, August 22, 2000.
scite3: Ted Oliver, "Troops back as loyalists go to war," Scottish Daily Record, August 22, 2000.

location: Gloucestershire. A farm at Syreford, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire
summary: 8/20/2000: An improvised explosive device (IED) was discovered on a stone wall at a farm in Syreford, Gloucestershire, Great Britain.  The homemade bomb consisted of at least one plastic bottle filled with explosive liquid, a timer, and 500 metal nuts.  The timer had failed to go off.  It is unclear whether the device was intended to target a fox hunt or was a failed test.  No group claimed responsibility.
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources speculate that the explosive device was intended to harm fox hunters
weapdetail: A homemade bomb consisting of at least one plastic bottle filled with explosive liquid, 500 brass nuts, and a timer
addnotes: It is possible that the explosive was put there simply to test whether it worked.
scite1: Geoffrey Gibbs, "Bomb linked to anti-hunt activists," The Guardian, August 22, 2000.
scite2: Conal Urquhart, "Bomb found at foxhunt farm," The Times, August 22, 2000.
scite3: "Police find cache of explosives in rural woods," Associated Press, August 26, 2000.

A workshop and offices were damaged in the explosion but no one was hurt.  This was one of four bombs placed in Basque country that day.  Authorities state that the attack was likely orchestrated by members of Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA) in an effort to extort a "revolutionary tax" from business owners.
target1: A construction company in San Sebastian
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources speculate that Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA) is trying to extort a "revolutionary tax" from local business owners
propcomment: A workshop and offices were damaged

This was one of four bombs placed in Basque country that day.  Authorities state that the attack was likely orchestrated by members of Basque Fatherland and Freedom (ETA) in an effort to extort a "revolutionary tax" from business owners.

summary: 08/25/2000: A car belonging to military attache, Prentex Stephanovis, at the Yugoslav Embassy was torched in Athens, Greece, The attack was later claimed by an anarchist group Anarchist Struggle. There were no injuries.
corp1: Millitary Attache at the Yugoslav Embassy
target1: Car belonging to Yugoslav military attache in Greece, Prentex Stephanovis
motive: An anarchist group called Anarchist Struggle said it had carried out the attack to protest against the detention of Symeon Ceisitis, who was being held by Greek authorities for various criminal acts.
weapdetail: A parked car was sprinkled with gasoline and set on fire.
propcomment: The targeted car was burned.
addnotes: In a phone call to the private radio station, Flash, shortly afterward, a group called Anarchist Struggle said it carried out the attack to protest against the detention by Greece of Symeon Ceisitis. Another anarchist group two days prior to the attack claimed the burning of another diplomat's car for the same reason.
scite1: “Yugoslav diplomat’s car burnt in Athens,” Agence France-Presse (North European Service), August 25, 2000.

location: Basauri, in Greater Bilbao, Vizcaya Province
summary: 8/25/2000: A homemade incendiary device exploded outside of the main door of the home of a member of the National Police Corps in Basauri, Greater Bilbao, Vizcaya province, Spain.  The homemade device consisted of two gas canisters and a firework primer.  One of the cylinders exploded, damaging the doorway.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: A member of the National Police Corps
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two gas canisters and a firework primer
propcomment: Minor damage to the doorway and landing
addnotes: Group and motive are unknown
scite1: "Bomb explodes at policeman's home in Basque Country," RNE Radio 1, August 25, 2000.

location: The Departmental Directorate of Infrastructure [DDE] government building in Bastia
summary: 8/26/2000: A bomb exploded outside the Departmental Directorate of Infrastructure [DDE] government building in Bastia, Corsica Island, France.  The explosion was caused by a two kilogram bomb consisting of plastic explosives.  The building was slightly damaged and several windows were broken in the explosion but no one was injured.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: The Departmental Directorate of Infrastructure [DDE] building in Bastia
motive: Unknown
